Notes: Curbs on in-person learning and public gatherings were extended to Feb 21    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312122646/https://bdnews24.com/education/2022/03/12/bangladesh-secondary-schools-colleges-to-resume-regular-classes-on-mar-15-education-minister

Secondary schools and colleges are still holding a limited number of in-person classes based on a revised schedule. SSC examinees and 10th-graders are being taught four and three subjects respectively on weekdays. Students of classes eight and nine are attending classes twice a week for three subjects, while sixth and seventh graders only have one class a week on one subject. Normal class schedules for secondary schools and colleges will resume on 15th March.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312122646/https://bdnews24.com/education/2022/03/12/bangladesh-secondary-schools-colleges-to-resume-regular-classes-on-mar-15-education-minister

Officials have also lifted the system of varied quarantine periods based on travel origin. Symptomatic entrants - regardless of vaccination status - will undergo on-arrival testing; individuals who test positive must enter self-paid quarantine at a government facility or hotel for at least seven days. A repeat PCR test will occur after seven days; passengers must quarantine until they receive a negative test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220310040729/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/bangladesh-authorities-lift-quarantine-for-asymptomatic-entrants-pre-departure-covid-19-test-requirement-for-vaccinated-arrivals-as-of-march-10-update-67

All the schools should ensure that COVID-19 protocol is in place and strictly observe it; SoPs should be upheld and followed by everyone in the schools; Along with the COVID-19 protocols and SoPs, the school managements are requested to pay extra attention to ensuring the security of the campus so that no trespassing by strangers or unauthorized exit of the campus by students/staff happens.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305051341/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-22-reminder-to-the-school-management-on-strict-enforcement-of-sops-and-covid-19-protocols-moe/

In the Gewogs (Samtse and Norbugang), Only essential shops identified and approved by the Dzongkhag/Gewog Essential Services Team shall be allowed to open from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM. The identified essential shops must undergo an RT-PCR test prior to the opening of shops. The identified essential shops must operate under self-containment mode.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305044435/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Notification-on-Activation-of-Zoning-System-for-Samtse-and-Norbugang-Gewog.pdf

The identified essential shops must operate under self-containment mode.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305044435/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Notification-on-Activation-of-Zoning-System-for-Samtse-and-Norbugang-Gewog.pdf

One individual from each household in Samtse Throm shall be allowed to move with a movement card within the respective zone for essential shopping. The zone timing is as follows: M: 9:00 AM â 12:00 Noon A: 2:00 PM â 5:00 PM In the Gewogs (Samtse and Norbugang), the movement shall be restricted within the Chiwogs. Inter-Gewog and Inter-Chiwog movement shall NOT be allowed. Individuals shall be allowed to carry out farming and livestock activities within their premises without interacting with neighbors. NO movement shall be allowed from Red Building/Cluster. Individuals coming out for essential shopping must follow all the COVID-19 protocols (wearing a mask, hand washing, using Druk Trace App., and physical distancing, etc.) at all times. NO movement of vehicles is allowed unless authorized for essential purposes. Medical emergencies shall be attended to and their movement will be facilitated upon verification by concerned health personnel.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305044435/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Notification-on-Activation-of-Zoning-System-for-Samtse-and-Norbugang-Gewog.pdf

All individuals entering Bhutan must quarantine at a government quarantine center upon arrival. Vaccinated individuals must quarantine for 14 days; those who are unvaccinated or arriving with unvaccinated children must quarantine for 21 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045827/https://in.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/bhutan-affairs/american-citizen-services-information/

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045842/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There are Coordinated Public information campaigns such as National Covid-19 Outbreak Phasing Map and Covid-19 Apps.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045834/https://www.moh.gov.bt/

PCR and/or antigen tests are generally available at the numerous flu clinics located throughout Bhutan.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045827/https://in.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/bhutan-affairs/american-citizen-services-information/
The healthcare officials do comprehensive contact tracing of the majority of cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045834/https://www.moh.gov.bt/

In the Gewogs (Samtse and Norbugang), individuals coming out for essential shopping must follow all the COVID-19 protocols (wearing mask, hand washing, using Druk Trace App., and physical distancing, etc.) at all times.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220305044435/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Notification-on-Activation-of-Zoning-System-for-Samtse-and-Norbugang-Gewog.pdf    Face masks are almost universally required to be worn in public, especially in urban areas, indoors, and on public transportation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045827/https://in.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/bhutan-affairs/american-citizen-services-information/

No coding change, but note that significantly more states have fully or partly reopened schools on 7 Feb. See note on 1 Feb 2022 for earlier wave of reopenings.     Coding explanation: Strictest measure coded for. Due to many more states reopening, the present 3T coding now is however, largely due to the situation in *Jammu and Kashmir*, where schools are still fully closed to students regardless of vaccination status. Otherwise do note that many areas: 1) Have reopened schools for at least some grades of students 2) Have vaccine differentiated policies (i.e at least 1 vaccine dose as a prerequisite for students to return to school in person.)    *A.	Continued closure:* Jammu and Kashmir â Schools closed since 10 Jan: https://archive.vn/SKhMJ   -	1 Feb update: Schools in Kashmir and winter zones of Jammu were told to observe winter vacation until 28 Feb. https://archive.vn/pZjS9  -	4 Feb update: School reopening is likely to only be in mid-Feb. https://archive.vn/l63mS     *B.	Reopenings:*    1.	NDTV article â Documents total or partial reopening for Delhi, Bihar, Kerala, Odisha and Uttar Pradesh on 7 Feb: https://archive.vn/EHino    *Areas with existing vaccine requirements for students:*     1.	Chandigarh: âAll students above the age of 15 who have received the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine can attend offline classes.â https://archive.vn/S2OGk#selection-1029.48-1029.165     2.	Punjab:     -	Reopening for classes 6 and above on 7 Feb, higher education institutions. Lower classes will continue remote learning until further notice. https://archive.vn/nbPow  https://archive.vn/oxdtz    -	Punjab students to have at least 1 vaccine dose before returning to school in person. [Link 1] https://archive.vn/nbPow#selection-2133.0-2136.0 [Link 2] https://archive.vn/oxdtz    *Other states that fully or partly reopened on 7 Feb:*     1.	Gujarat â In-person lessons to resume for classes 1â9 on 7 Feb https://archive.vn/mmA2T     2.	Uttar Pradesh â Significant as the Indian state with largest population. https://archive.vn/21Hgv     3.	Biharâ Schools allowed to hold physical classes with 50 per cent attendance for up to class 8. No restrictions for classes 9 upwards. https://archive.vn/H8Hzx     4.	Delhi â Partial reopening for classes 9 and above, classes below to reopen on 14 Feb. https://archive.vn/5dn4z     5.	Odisha â Partial reopening for classes 8-12; some grades (kindergarten to class 7) will reopen on 14 Feb instead. https://archive.vn/PsKzD     6.	Puducherry â Reopened earlier for colleges and classes 1â12 on 4 Feb https://archive.vn/QBceA
No policy change. Rules depend on the state but the state of Jammu and Kashmir is in winter vacation until February 28th.  https://archive.ph/1b9G9
Article contains "List of States That Have Closed Schools". Jammu and Kashmir is still wholly online. Other states have opened classes for some levels.   https://archive.ph/Wu973

Assam has a stay-at-home order for unvaccinated until February 15th, including work places. retail shops may have in place limited hours and/or limits on the number of patrons allowed inside. Further, there are some required closings of shopping malls.  https://archive.vn/Hgcef  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Retail shops may have in place limited hours and/or limits on the number of patrons allowed inside. Further, there are some required closings of shopping malls.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No general ban but there are regional restrictions in place that can lead to the cancellation of public events, like some election campaigns.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://archive.ph/fDaz8

Very complicated system in which every state decides independently and on a case-by-case basis. Assam has a stay-at-home order for unvaccinated until February 15th.   https://archive.vn/Hgcef    Election rallies for upcoming state elections banned, but groups of 20 people for doorstep campaigning and up to 1,000 people for political meetings permitted.  https://archive.ph/fDaz8  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Assam still has pretty tough restrictions in place - with some differentiation by vaccination status - unvaccinated people not allowed in public places - hence coding *4T*   Some states, like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka appear to be easing restrictions, allowing 250 - 500 people in gatherings (no vacc status specified).    Assam only allows 40-60 vaccinated people in religious places.      https://archive.ph/2m6Iz  Assam: The ASDMA said non-vaccinated people will not be allowed to enter public places, except hospitals.  "All people are required to carry proof of being fully vaccinated while visiting public places/spaces. The owners of public/private establishments shall be responsible for ensuring that only those entrants who are fully vaccinated are allowed inside and this has to be done scrupulously by checking their vaccination status."  "In case of marriages and meetings, up to 200 people or 50 per cent of capacity of a venue, whichever is less, will be allowed.  Up to 60 fully vaccinated people will be permitted to enter iconic religious places in an hour, while the limit is 40 for other such places."    https://archive.ph/QbE7H    Tamil Nadu:   "Between March 3 and 31, weddings and other related functions can be held with the participation of 500 people while the number for deaths and funerals should not exceed 250, it said.  The numbers were earlier capped at 200 for weddings and 100 for death-related ceremonies."  https://archive.ph/BhFTD#selection-1127.0-1127.182    Karnataka:   "Demonstrations are banned; permitted gatherings must be limited to 300 people if outdoors, and 200 people if indoors."  https://archive.ph/t7wCp#selection-1995.0-1997.119

Is public transportation operating? Yes, though hours of operation vary throughout India depending on regional COVID-19 measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  In Maharashtra, there is still a ban for unvaccinated on public transport.  https://archive.ph/qSFuQ

Reversion from *3T* to *3T/2T* coding due to the authorities in Jammu and Kashmir deciding to end its weekend lockdown, which had applied to vaccinated and unvaccinated from 5â6 Feb. See 1 Feb note for more details on vaccine differentiated coding and ongoing curfews from 1 Febâ7 Feb in other states which justify the 3T (unvaccinated) / 2T (vaccinated) coding.   Archived source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220207145536/https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/india/covid-no-weekend-lockdown-in-jk-night-curfew-relaxed-by-an-hour/articleshow/89390713.cms

Assam has a stay-at-home order for unvaccinated until February 15th. Local restrictions on vaccinated or unvaccinated can apply in different areas of the country.  https://archive.vn/Hgcef  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No coding change from previous notes. Most states and union territories still require a minimum of a Covid-19 vaccination certificate and/or negative PCR test results from domestic travellers.    https://archive.ph/mBi7x

No policy change since last update. Policy is not vaccine differentiated: all international travellers, whether arriving via air, sea or land ports, must still complete a 7 day home quarantine, regardless of vaccination status, and take PCR tests at various times after arrival. It not possible to âtest outâ of quarantine early either.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. Some form of debt relief seems to be continuing, as seen from the national government recently approving further allocations to reimburse lenders to support the loan moratorium scheme, which would presumably in turn support the ability to offer debt relief for borrowers, including households.     See the following example from January: âBy granting ex-gratia payment of difference between compound interest and simple interest during the six month moratorium period to distressed/vulnerable category of borrowers, irrespective of whether the borrower had availed of moratorium or not, the scheme would equitably help small borrowers bear the stress on account of the pandemic and get back on their feet, said an official release.â   https://archive.ph/RL5zX

Comprehensive public information campaign to date; on various websites and platforms. Extensive statistics on COVID-19 cases, vaccinations and state measures are provided, and in multiple different languages, on a national and state level. Pages are usually updated daily.    For example: https://web.archive.org/web/20220129175811/https://www.mygov.in/covid-19

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in India? Yes, tests are available throughout India in both private and government facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No changes. Contact tracing continues to be classified as limited. There is evidence of some contact tracing being done, but it is not comprehensive enough to stop the spread. States seem to be cautious to reduce the number of people working in contact tracing. In combination with a lower number of cases this might lead to a more comprehensive contact tracing.  https://archive.ph/LxSYT

Face masks are almost universally required to be worn in public, especially in urban areas, indoors, and on public transportation.  These regulations are being strictly enforced.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301000125/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are open under health guidelines and some restrictions on class sizes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308010759/http:/www.adaderana.lk/news/79600/schools-reopen-in-sri-lanka

COVID 19 restrictions continue through Feb. Workplaces are open but with reduced capacity or other restrictive measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

Most workplaces are open with strict adherence to COVID precautions. A few are open with reduced capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

COVID 19 restrictions continue through Feb. Some events may happen but most are required to cancel due to the restrictions on capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

As of Mar 01, COVID 19 restrictions have been eased. Gatherings for up to 75% of the capacity of halls are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

Public transport is running with methods in place to make them safer including a) only seated passengers in public transport b) public and shared transport should preferably be non-air-conditioned, c) windows should be opened d) all passengers should wear a mask properly during travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223
Public transport is running with some safety measures in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

COVID 19 restrictions continue through Feb. People are advised to avoid unnecessary travel out of the home, in order to minimise risk of transmission of COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223
People are recommended to stay at home    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

There is no curfew in place but people are encouraged to stay at home to avoid risk of transmission    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223
Although there is no curfew in place, people are recommended to stay at home    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

Unvaccinated travellers are required to quarantine for 7 days and are required to do PCR test on Day 1 and Day 7.    Fully vaccinated travellers are required to present a negative PCR or Rapid Antigen test done within 48 hours prior to emabarkation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223

As of Mar 01, restrictions have been eased for fully vaccinated travellers. They do not need a pre-embarkation PCR test.    Unvaccinated and partially vaccinated individuals over 12 yeas of age are required to have a pre-embarkation test, quarantine for 7 days and get tested on Day 1 and Day 7 of arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220302032137/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=223
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110193309/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110193309/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There is a co-ordinated public health campaign through the Ministry of Health    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308014736/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=231

COVID-19 test in Sri Lanka can be done at any private hospital. The average cost per test is 9,000-13,000 Sri Lankan Rupees (approximately $50-$70).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306193418/https:/lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Contact tracing is being done    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308015140/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/library/Statistics.html
Face masks are required in all public places    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306193418/https:/lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Anyone over the age of 12 years is eligible to get vaccines.    Vaccines being used include Astra Zeneca, Sputnik V, Pfizer BionTech, Moderna and Sinopharm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308015140/http:/www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/library/Statistics.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308023455/https:/medicalxpress.com/news/2022-01-sri-lanka-vaccinates-children-doctors.html
Booster doses were prioritized for the elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213163048/https://medicalxpress.com/news/2021-11-sri-lanka-booster-jabs-virus.html

Anyone over the age of 12 years is eligible for vaccine.    Boosters are available to anyone over the age of 20.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308024314/http:/www.news.cn/english/2021-12/20/c_1310384213.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308023455/https:/medicalxpress.com/news/2022-01-sri-lanka-vaccinates-children-doctors.html

Vaccines are available to anyone over the age of 12 years.  Booster doses are available to anyone over the age of 20 years    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308023455/https:/medicalxpress.com/news/2022-01-sri-lanka-vaccinates-children-doctors.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220308024314/http:/www.news.cn/english/2021-12/20/c_1310384213.htm

Vaccines are fully funded by the Government    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308023455/https:/medicalxpress.com/news/2022-01-sri-lanka-vaccinates-children-doctors.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220308024314/http:/www.news.cn/english/2021-12/20/c_1310384213.htm
There does not appear to be any requirements for mandatory vaccination.

Nepal banned large public gatherings and closed schools across the Himalayan nation after a spike in coronavirus cases:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117201833/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-closes-schools-covid-19-cases-spike-2022-01-10/  Nepal schools to reopen from February 13:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207212005/https://english.onlinekhabar.com/nepal-schools-reopen.html

Nepal schools reopened from February 13:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214234133/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/schools-reopen-in-nepal-as-third-wave-of-covid-weakens/articleshow/89540371.cms

Nepal schools reopened from February 13:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214234133/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/schools-reopen-in-nepal-as-third-wave-of-covid-weakens/articleshow/89540371.cms

Lockdown lifted but all kinds of public gatherings, such as political rallies and mass meetings, jatras and religious festivals with large gatherings of people, remain banned in Kathmandu Valley until further notification.  Kathmandu has allowed movie halls, nightclubs, dohori restaurants to reopen at 50 per cent capacity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210903111134/https://thehimalayantimes.com/opinion/editorial-no-more-lockdown

Authorities maintain a requirement that people carry in public their vaccination cards and undertake social-distancing measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228211755/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/covid-19-nepal-to-reopen-schools-other-venues-as-coronavirus-cases-fall/article38391282.ece

Vaccination card mandatory to use public amenities from January 21 into force. There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to strict COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

When flying to Nepal from or through the UK, you will need to present certain documentation:    a certificate showing a negative Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) test, taken within 72 hours of flight of first departure.  a visa or prior approval document. Those certified vaccinated, can secure a visa on arrival  a travel insurance document which covers health, immediate crisis, or rescue for the duration of your travel  a barcode generated from the online application of the Online International Travel Arrival Form. See ARMS-DIMS  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117203348/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/coronavirus    If youâre not fully vaccinated or within 14 days of vaccination shall mandatorily obtain a prior visa from Nepali missions abroad.    You are required to submit the following documents when at the immigration entry point in Nepal: â¢ COVID-19 negative report obtained within 72 hours of the departure from the first port of embarkation. â¢ a travel insurance document which covers health, immediate crisis, or rescue for the duration of your travel â¢ Printed copy of International Traveller Online Arrival Form obtained after online registration ARMS-DIMS    Unvaccinated people, or those unable to show that they have been fully vaccinated for at least fourteen days, are subject to free antigen tests on arrival.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214234626/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/entry-requirements

Unvaccinated people, or those unable to show that they have been fully vaccinated for at least fourteen days, are subject to free antigen tests on arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220228212737/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/entry-requirements

All people are eligible for PCR testing in Nepal, with results arriving within 72 hours.  As per the latest data provided by the health ministry, a total of 17,465 tests were conducted in the last 24 hours of which 14,014 were PCR tests while 3,451 were antigen tests. With this, a total of 5,018,248 PCR tests have been carried out till date.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117203348/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/nepals-active-covid-19-caseload-advances-to-30877-as-5747-more-test-positive
